docs.title: Jupyter Notify Plus
docs.text:
Jupyter Notify Plus is a lightweight, powerful extension that adds:

  • %notifyme — end-of-cell notifications
  • %notifyme here — inline notifications
  • Presets: success, warn, error, failure
  • Custom icons, timestamps, and output inclusion
  • Works in classic Notebook and JupyterLab

docs.title: Why this exists
docs.text: Long-running notebook cells deserve better feedback. This extension gives you clean, modern browser notifications without any external dependencies.

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
%load_ext jupyternotifyplus

%notifyme success -t "Done" -m "Futures updated"

%notifyme here warn "Starting download"
download_data()

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• 🔔 Inline notifications
  • 🧭 End-of-cell notifications
  • 🎨 Preset icons and styles
  • 🧪 Fully tested (Windows-safe)
  • 📦 Installable via pip
  • 🧰 Zero dependencies

docs.title: Development
docs.text:
Clone the repository:

git clone https://github.com/yourname/jupyternotifyplus
cd jupyternotifyplus

Install in editable mode:

pip install -e .[dev]

Run tests:

pytest

Build the package:

python -m build

docs.title: Install from source
docs.text:
pip install jupyternotifyplus

Or from a local checkout:

pip install -e .

docs.title: Load the extension
docs.text:
In any Jupyter Notebook:

%load_ext jupyternotifyplus

You’re ready to go.

docs.title: %notifyme
docs.text: Triggers a notification after the cell completes.

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description -t Title -m Message -o Include output in message --icon Custom icon URL

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
%notifyme -t "Finished" -m "Processing complete"
%notifyme here

Triggers a notification immediately.

%notifyme here -t "Checkpoint" -m "Step 1 done"

docs.title: Presets
docs.text:
Presets provide default title, message, and icon.

Available presets:

  • success
  • warn
  • error
  • failure

docs.title: Inline presets
docs.text:
%notifyme here success "Step completed"
%notifyme here warn "Something odd happened"

docs.title: End-of-cell presets
docs.text:
%notifyme success
%notifyme failure

docs.title: Presets with overrides
docs.text: %notifyme success -t "Download complete" -m "Futures updated"

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Tests are written using pytest.

Windows-specific issues with IPython history are handled by:

os.environ["IPYTHON_HISTORY"] = "0"
ip.history_manager.enabled = False

pytest

All tests should pass cleanly on Windows, macOS, and Linux.

docs.title: Usage Overview
docs.text:
Once loaded:

%load_ext jupyternotifyplus

You have two main commands: - %notifyme — triggers a notification after the cell finishes - %notifyme here — triggers a notification immediately at that line

docs.title: End-of-cell notification
docs.text: %notifyme -t "Done" -m "Cell finished"

docs.title: Inline notification
docs.text:
%notifyme here -t "Checkpoint" -m "Reached step 1"

You can use as many inline notifications as you want.

docs.title: Variable and Expression Resolution
docs.text:
%notifyme supports Python variable names, expressions, and f‑strings inside the -t (title) and -m (message) arguments.

This allows you to write expressive, dynamic notifications without string‑escaping or manual formatting.

docs.title: Using variables
docs.text:
a = "Hello World"
%notifyme success -t a

The notification title becomes:

Hello World

docs.title: Using f‑strings
docs.text:
%notifyme success -t f"1+1={1+1}"

Title:

1+1=2

docs.title: Using expressions
docs.text:
%notifyme -t "3 * 7"

Title:

21

docs.title: Resolution Rules
docs.text:
%notifyme resolves values using the following logic:

  1. If the argument matches a variable name in the user namespace, its value is used.

  2. Otherwise, the argument is evaluated as a Python expression (e.g., f‑strings, arithmetic).

  3. If evaluation fails, the literal string is used unchanged.

This makes %notifyme flexible while remaining safe and predictable.
